conversation.content: [nervously] You're the technician?
Yeah, I'm here to assess the damage and install a new meter. [pause] The police report said it was intentional destruction, spray paint and a baseball bat apparently.

[shaky voice] I'm so sorry about what Tyler did to your equipment. [quietly] I know an apology doesn't fix anything, but I wanted to meet you in person before you started the work, to at least try to explain.

[hesitantly] Look, ma'am, I appreciate you coming out here, but this is the third meter I've had destroyed this month. [sighs] Kids think it's funny to mess with utility equipment, not realizing someone has to fix it.

[frustrated] He's not my biological son, I've only been his stepmother for two years, and honestly, I don't know how to reach him anymore. [voice breaking] His father works overseas contracts, gone eight months out of twelve, and Tyler blames me for everything wrong in his life.

[bitter] That meter he destroyed was one I'd just installed last week, took me three hours in ninety-degree heat to get it properly calibrated. [quietly] My supervisor's threatening to dock my pay for the replacement costs since it happened on my route.

[apologetic] We'll cover everything, all the costs, your time, whatever penalties there are. [anxiously] I've already talked to our lawyer about restitution, and Tyler's going to work all summer to pay it back, though he doesn't know that yet.
[slowly] You know what really gets me? I have a seventeen-year-old son too, and [sighs] last year he got caught shoplifting because his friends dared him to.
[surprised] You have a teenager? [empathetically] Then you understand how they can just suddenly become these strangers living in your house, angry at the world and taking it out on anyone nearby.
[warmly] The shoplifting wasn't even about the stuff, it was about his mom and me divorcing. [pause] Kids don't know how to process big emotions, so they break things instead.
[relieved] That's exactly it, Tyler's mom died three years ago, and his dad remarried me so fast, and now [trembling] I'm trying to parent this kid who sees me as the enemy who replaced his mother.
[confidently] My son's doing better now, working part-time, staying out of trouble. Sometimes they just need to hit bottom before they can start climbing back up.

[very quietly] I keep wondering if I should just leave, let his father deal with this when he gets back from Kuwait, but that feels like abandoning Tyler when [sighs] maybe what he needs is someone who won't give up on him.
Ma'am, I'm going to be honest with you, the fact that you're here, talking to me directly instead of just sending a check through your insurance, that says something about the kind of person you are.

Tyler doesn't even know I'm here, he'd probably be mortified, but I needed to do this for myself too, to feel like I'm doing something constructive instead of just yelling and grounding him over and over.
[hesitantly] Look, I do youth mentoring through my church on weekends. [quietly] If Tyler needs someone to talk to who isn't family, who's been through some stuff, I could give you my card.
[crying while speaking] You'd do that? After what he did to your equipment? [gratefully] I don't even know what to say, that's incredibly generous of you.
[formal] I need to get this meter installed before my next appointment, but think about it. [warmly] Sometimes kids listen better to strangers than family.
[sincerely] Thank you for not just seeing us as another problem household. [pause] I'll talk to Tyler tonight, see if he's open to meeting you properly, under better circumstances.
[chuckling] Better circumstances than vandalism? Yeah, that'd be good.

scenario: A stepmother dealing with her teenage stepson's recent arrest for vandalism encounters the meter technician whose electric meter was destroyed in the incident.
